questions.article: During his career, Cuban composer and pianist Ernesto Lecuona produced hundreds of compositions. Especially impressive is how ______ his body of work is: Lecuona showcased a diverse range of musical talents in different areas, from orchestral pieces and operas to popular film scores.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: outdated

options.name: B
options.content: lonely

options.name: C
options.content: forgotten

options.name: D
options.content: varied

questions.correct: varied

questions.article: As with other river deltas, the Indus River delta is ______: it is a constantly evolving network of channels and strips of land that change in size and shape as the river deposits new sedimentary particles where the river meets the waters of the Arabian Sea.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: dynamic

options.name: B
options.content: sustainable

options.name: C
options.content: immutable

options.name: D
options.content: unrivaled

questions.correct: dynamic

questions.article:
The following text is from Amy Tan's 1989 novel The Joy Luck Club. The narrator describes practicing the piano when she was a child.

For the talent show, I was to play a piece called "Pleading Child" from Schumann's Scenes from Childhood. It was a simple, moody piece that sounded more difficult than it was. I was supposed to memorize the whole thing, playing the repeat parts twice to make the piece sound longer. But I dawdled over it, playing a few bars and then cheating, looking up to see what notes followed. I never really listened to what I was playing. I daydreamed about being somewhere else, about being someone else.

©1989 by Amy Tan
questions.question: Based on the text, when the narrator describes herself as "cheating," what does she most likely mean?

options.name: A
options.content: She was violating an expectation about how to perform the piece.

options.name: B
options.content: She was gaining an unfair advantage over other contestants in the talent show.

options.name: C
options.content: She was deceiving her piano teacher.

options.name: D
options.content: She was lying to herself about her musical ability.

questions.correct: She was violating an expectation about how to perform the piece.

questions.article:
The following text is from Bram Stoker's 1911 novel The Lair of the White Worm. Adam is meeting his great-uncle Richard at a port.

The meeting so auspiciously begun proceeded well. Adam, seeing that the old man was interested in the novelty of the ship, suggested that he should stay the night on board, and that he would himself be ready to start at any hour and go anywhere that the other suggested. This affectionate willingness to fall in with his own plans quite won the old man's heart. He warmly accepted the invitation, and at once they became not only on terms of affectionate relationship, but almost like old friends.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It showcases how Adam's flexibility and consideration strengthen his relationship with his great-uncle Richard.

options.name: B
options.content: It states the reasons why Adam and his great-uncle Richard decide to sleep on the ship rather than finding lodging on land.

options.name: C
options.content: It describes why Adam and his great-uncle Richard are excited for their upcoming journey on the ship.

options.name: D
options.content: It contrasts great-uncle Richard's wary first impressions of Adam with his ultimate affection toward him.

questions.correct: It showcases how Adam's flexibility and consideration strengthen his relationship with his great-uncle Richard.

questions.article: Vertical gene transfer involves the transmission of genetic material from a parent to offspring; horizontal gene transfer, on the other hand, involves the exchange of genetic material between organisms not in a parent-offspring relationship. While horizontal gene transfer is common among prokaryotes—single-celled organisms such as the bacteria Carnobacterium viridans and Moraxella caviae—it has rarely been observed among eukaryotes (typically multicellular organisms). However, new studies suggest that horizontal gene transfer is more common in eukaryotes than originally thought.
questions.question: Which choice best states the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It argues that a particular direction of research concerning horizontal gene transfer is likely to be fruitless.

options.name: B
options.content: It indicates a distinction between horizontal gene transfer and vertical gene transfer.

options.name: C
options.content: It implies that a common perception of horizontal gene transfer may be inaccurate.

options.name: D
options.content: It compares the frequencies with which horizontal gene transfer has been detected in two categories of organisms.

questions.correct: It implies that a common perception of horizontal gene transfer may be inaccurate.

questions.article: Though John Crowley, author of Endless Things, is perhaps not as well known as the most widely read American writers of the past fifty years, influential figures have championed his work, including the poet James Merrill and the literary critic Harold Bloom. In his afterword to Crowley's book Little, Big, Bloom praises the novel's adroit blend of what playwright Friedrich Schiller termed the naive and sentimental modes—while Schiller thought works could be classified as either naive (seeking to describe reality) or sentimental (seeking to develop ideas), Little, Big demonstrates that a work can be both.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To explain what inspired an author to write a particular work.

options.name: B
options.content: To present a reason why a literary critic is impressed by a certain novel.

options.name: C
options.content: To compare the work of a writer with the work of a poet who admired him.

options.name: D
options.content: To argue that all writing must be classified as belonging to one of two categories.

questions.correct: To present a reason why a literary critic is impressed by a certain novel.

questions.article:
The following text is from a translation of Maria Dueñas's 2009 novel The Time in Between. The narrator has just rented an apartment and is entering it for the first time.

Over the years there have been many times when my destiny has delivered me unexpected moments, unforeseen twists and turns that I've had to handle on the fly as they appeared. Occasionally I was ready for them; very often I wasn't. Never, however, was I so aware of entering a new stage as I was that afternoon in October when I finally dared to cross the threshold and my steps sounded hollowly in the unfurnished apartment. Behind me was a complicated past, and in front of me, like an omen, I could see a space opening out, a great empty space that time would take care of filling up.

©2009 by Maria Dueñas. Translation ©2011 by Haniel Haha.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: The narrator feels optimistic about the future success of a new business.

options.name: B
options.content: The narrator has always had a plan for how to handle big moments in her life.

options.name: C
options.content: The narrator recognizes that a particular moment marks a major shift in her life.

options.name: D
options.content: The narrator wants to express her gratitude for the people who have helped her.

questions.correct: The narrator recognizes that a particular moment marks a major shift in her life.

questions.article: The soil on Mars can make missions to explore the planet challenging, as the sand and dust are known to clog filters and lock moving parts on robotic rovers and other exploration devices. Using simulants, which are materials designed to simulate different planetary surfaces, scientists are able to study the characteristics of Mars's surface. Simulants like the Mars Mojave simulant—which was developed using lava deposits from California's Mojave Desert—help scientists evaluate how well their devices will handle the surface when operated on Mars.
questions.question: Based on the text, what is one reason why simulants are valuable for scientists?

options.name: A
options.content: Scientists use simulants to track how the chemical properties of planetary soils have changed over time.

options.name: B
options.content: Scientists use simulants to compare the physical properties of Mars's surface to those of Earth's surface.

options.name: C
options.content: Simulants can be mixed with soil from Earth to explore how research equipment will handle extreme terrains on Earth.

options.name: D
options.content: Simulants allow scientists to test the ability of research equipment to withstand some of the conditions it will encounter during a mission.

questions.correct: Simulants allow scientists to test the ability of research equipment to withstand some of the conditions it will encounter during a mission.

questions.article: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz is a 1900 novel by L. Frank Baum. In the novel, the narrator describes a character's house as having become very faded in appearance over time: ______
questions.question: Which quotation from The Wonderful Wizard of Oz most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: "Once more [Dorothy and her companions] could see fences built beside the road; but these were painted green, and when they came to a small house, in which a farmer evidently lived, that also was painted green."

options.name: B
options.content: "Then [Dorothy] went back to the house, and having, helped herself and Toto to a good drink of the cool, clear water, she set about making ready for the journey to the City of Emeralds."

options.name: C
options.content: "Once the house had been painted, but the sun blistered the paint and the rains washed it away, and now the house was as dull and gray as everything else."

options.name: D
options.content: "When Dorothy stood in the doorway and looked around, she could see nothing but the great gray prairie on every side. Not a tree nor a house broke the broad sweep of flat country."

questions.correct: "Once the house had been painted, but the sun blistered the paint and the rains washed it away, and now the house was as dull and gray as everything else."

questions.article: As the second-most populous continent in the world, Africa was home to an estimated 1.186 billion people in 2015. In a paper for a social studies class, a student nonetheless notes that countries with very large populations may be less densely populated than are countries with much smaller populations, as can be seen by comparing ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the example?

options.name: A
options.content: the geographic size of Angola (1,246,700 square kilometers) with its relatively high population of 25,022,000 inhabitants.

options.name: B
options.content: Angola, which has a high population of 25,022,000 inhabitants and a relatively low density of 20.1 inhabitants/square kilometer, with Sao Tomé and Principe, which has a much lower population and a higher density.

options.name: C
options.content: Mauritania, which has a low density, with Ethiopia, which has a similar density despite both countries having different geographic sizes.

options.name: D
options.content: the populations of both Sao Tomé and Principe and Ethiopia in 2015 with their populations in 2010.

questions.correct: Angola, which has a high population of 25,022,000 inhabitants and a relatively low density of 20.1 inhabitants/square kilometer, with Sao Tomé and Principe, which has a much lower population and a higher density.

questions.article: To measure whether countries in free trade agreements (FTAs)—agreements among nations to reduce tariffs, duties, and other trade barriers—experience changes in total agricultural exports, economist Kayode Ajewole and colleagues calculated average export growth rates for several countries over the five years before and the five years after entering an FTA with the United States. The graph shows the results for three countries in the study. Consulting the graph, a student claims that joining an FTA increases the rate of growth of a country's total agricultural exports.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the graph that weaken the student's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: All the countries shown had positive growth in agricultural exports over the five years after joining their respective FTAs, but their rates of export growth varied.

options.name: B
options.content: Although agricultural exports from Nicaragua grew over the five years after Nicaragua joined CAFTA-DR, their growth rate was even higher in the five years before CAFTA-DR.

options.name: C
options.content: Although agricultural exports from Mexico decreased over the five years before NAFTA, a reversal in this trend was observed over the five years after Mexico joined NAFTA.

options.name: D
options.content: Over the five years after El Salvador joined CAFTA-DR, agricultural exports from El Salvador grew at a rate of about 21.8 percent, which is higher than the rate over the five years before El Salvador joined the agreement.

questions.correct: Although agricultural exports from Nicaragua grew over the five years after Nicaragua joined CAFTA-DR, their growth rate was even higher in the five years before CAFTA-DR.

questions.article: If a planet orbits in close proximity to a star and lacks an atmosphere, the planet can become so hot that magma oceans form on its surface. For three planets that could plausibly harbor magma oceans, the table shows mass, density (expressed as the ratio of the material's volume at its current density to its maximum possible density, with higher numbers indicating lower densities), and surface temperature according to a model that assumes the absence of atmosphere.
questions.question: Which choice best describes how data in the table for HD 80653 b would likely differ if it had an atmosphere?

options.name: A
options.content: It would have a mass below 5.6 Earth masses.

options.name: B
options.content: Its surface temperature would be around 1,400 kelvins.

options.name: C
options.content: It would have a mass above 5.6 Earth masses.

options.name: D
options.content: Its surface temperature would be below 2,300 kelvins.

questions.correct: Its surface temperature would be below 2,300 kelvins.

questions.article: Michelle Pereira et al. hypothesized that introducing health improvements into workplaces would increase productivity by reducing absenteeism (sick employees not working) and presenteeism (sick workers working less productively due to illness). Pereira's team enrolled groups of Australian workers in two programs; one that gave employees exercise training (EET) and one that enrolled employees in health promotion seminars (EHP). They then calculated the productivity loss of those groups at 12 weeks and 12 months after the programs began (based on the 28 days preceding each point). They concluded that exercise training was more effective at restraining productivity loss than health promotion seminars were, though this result took time to become apparent.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the table that most effectively strengthen Pereira and colleagues' conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Productivity loss for the EET group barely decreased between 12 weeks and 12 months after the program began, while productivity loss for the EHP group significantly increased during the same time period.

options.name: B
options.content: Productivity loss was largely due to absenteeism for the EHP group at 12 months after the program began, while productivity loss was largely due to presenteeism for the EET group at 12 months after the program began.

options.name: C
options.content: Productivity loss was consistently higher for the EHP group than for the EET group over the twelve months that it was measured, though the size of the difference between the two decreased over that time.

options.name: D
options.content: Productivity loss was fairly similar for the EET and EHP groups 12 weeks after each program began, but at 12 months afterward it had significantly increased for the EHP group and significantly decreased for the EET group.

questions.correct: Productivity loss was fairly similar for the EET and EHP groups 12 weeks after each program began, but at 12 months afterward it had significantly increased for the EHP group and significantly decreased for the EET group.

questions.article: Ningyo joruri is a form of theater that was popular in eighteenth-century Japan and that unites puppetry with playing of the shamisen, a stringed musical instrument. The popularity of ningyo joruri was due to a puppetry method called sannin zukai, in which three puppeteers operated a single puppet that was large, detailed, and capable of extensive movement and nuanced emotional expression. Over the ensuing centuries, audience interest in ningyo joruri began to decline and sannin zukai became prohibitively expensive to mount, so that sannin zukai puppeteers could no longer make the profession a full-time career. Eventually, ningyo joruri productions resorted to cheaper forms of puppetry, such as kuruma ningyo, which involves only one puppeteer.
questions.question: Which statement, if true, would most strongly support the claim in the underlined sentence?

options.name: A
options.content: The kuruma ningyo puppeteering method is not easy: it requires fewer puppeteers to manipulate puppets that are as large as those used in sannin zukai, but each puppeteer's work is more complex.

options.name: B
options.content: The costs of building sannin zukai puppets were very high until the advent of machine-based production methods in the nineteenth century made them comparable to the costs of building kuruma ningyo puppets.

options.name: C
options.content: In 1872, Japanese puppeteer Nishikawa Koryu developed a technique called kuruma ningyo, or cart puppetry, in which puppets have wooden pegs on their feet that the puppeteer can manipulate by moving his own feet.

options.name: D
options.content: The few remaining theatrical companies with sannin zukai performers in the present day are mostly amateur troupes, in which members have other forms of employment that serve as their primary source of income.

questions.correct: The few remaining theatrical companies with sannin zukai performers in the present day are mostly amateur troupes, in which members have other forms of employment that serve as their primary source of income.

questions.article: Both Pontianak, Indonesia, and Manta, Ecuador, are located at less than one degree latitude. In other words, ______ cities basically sit right on the equator!
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: these

options.name: B
options.content: each

options.name: C
options.content: that

options.name: D
options.content: this

questions.correct: these

questions.article: An upcoming exhibition will showcase Vincent van Gogh's drawing Sale of Building Scrap, which Van Gogh ______ in the city of Nuenen nearly 150 years ago.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: has been completing

options.name: B
options.content: is completing

options.name: C
options.content: will complete

options.name: D
options.content: completed

questions.correct: completed

questions.article: The rough frog is a species of amphibian native to Australia. Currently, the frog's range ______ parts of northern New South Wales and southeastern Queensland.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: had included

options.name: B
options.content: will have included

options.name: C
options.content: includes

options.name: D
options.content: included

questions.correct: includes

questions.article: When attempting to determine a fault's seismic history, geophysicists like Dr. Estella Atekwana at the University of Delaware rely in part on data about the fault's physical dimensions and geological features. For the Ione Valley fault in Lander County, Nevada, the US Geological Survey compiles such data in several ______ exchanging information with state geological surveys, by linking maps of the fault with sources that offer detailed descriptions of it, and by maintaining a database of quantitative data such as the fault's length (76 km).
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: ways. By

options.name: B
options.content: ways: by

options.name: C
options.content: ways; by

options.name: D
options.content: ways by:

questions.correct: ways: by

questions.article: A pet rabbit is held by its owner on a beach in Boo and His Rabbit, a photograph by British ______ Chris Killip.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: artist;

options.name: B
options.content: artist—

options.name: C
options.content: artist

options.name: D
options.content: artist,

questions.correct: artist

questions.article: In his 2011 book, historian Sebouh David Aslanian quantifies the reading patterns of early modern Armenian merchants from New Julfa. Aslanian's macroanalysis ______ nearly 1,000 book titles published between 1512 and 1800 shows not only the steady popularity of religious texts but also a broadening interest in secular books, especially those on history and geography.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: had examined

options.name: B
options.content: examining

options.name: C
options.content: examined

options.name: D
options.content: examines

questions.correct: examining

questions.article: In 1920, the US Geological Survey determined the geographic center of Tennessee using only a cardboard cutout of the state and a piece of string. ______ this apparently crude technique yielded a relatively close approximation: when the 1920 center was compared to a center determined by a computer program nearly a hundred years later, the two diverged by just a few miles.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Still,

options.name: B
options.content: Similarly,

options.name: C
options.content: In other words,

options.name: D
options.content: Fittingly,

questions.correct: Still,

questions.article: In astrophysics, a ring of debris orbiting a larger object within the object's Roche limit is expected to persist as a ring, whereas a ring of debris orbiting outside this limit would likely accrete into a satellite (e.g., a moon). Bruno Morgado and colleagues, ______ detected a dense ring of material orbiting the trans-Neptunian object Quaoar at a distance of 2,500 miles, well outside the calculated Roche limit of 1,100 miles, that has remained intact.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: likewise,

options.name: B
options.content: fittingly,

options.name: C
options.content: for example,

options.name: D
options.content: though,

questions.correct: though,

questions.article: While most animals prefer the safety of nighttime migration, many poisonous amphibians—a category that includes the Panamanian golden frog and the cane toad—safely engage in migratory behavior during the day. ______ with the sun in the sky, the amphibians' striking color patterns deter visually oriented daytime predators by serving as a warning of toxicity.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: However,

options.name: B
options.content: At that time,

options.name: C
options.content: In other words,

options.name: D
options.content: For example,

questions.correct: At that time,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Niger River is the third longest river in Africa.
  • It ranks No. 14 among the longest rivers in the world.
  • It is 4,200 kilometers long.
  • The Indus River is the ninth longest river in Asia.
  • It ranks No. 19 among the longest rivers in the world.
  • It is 3,610 kilometers long.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize the different locations of the two rivers. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The Indus River is 3,610 kilometers long.

options.name: B
options.content: The Niger River is in Africa, whereas the Indus River is located in Asia.

options.name: C
options.content: The Niger River ranks No. 14 among the longest rivers in the world.

options.name: D
options.content: At 4,200 kilometers long, the Niger River is the third longest in Africa.

questions.correct: The Niger River is in Africa, whereas the Indus River is located in Asia.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Mauritius Trade Union Congress (MTUC) is a national union federation for the African nation of Mauritius.
  • It helps improve conditions for workers in that nation.
  • ITUC-Africa is a regional union federation that represents national union federations across Africa.
  • It represents the MTUC.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to explain the purpose of national union federations?

options.name: A
options.content: The MTUC is one of the national union federations represented by ITUC-Africa.

options.name: B
options.content: The MTUC is a national union federation in Africa.

options.name: C
options.content: National union federations, such as the MTUC, work to improve conditions for workers in their member nations.

options.name: D
options.content: Regional union federations like ITUC-Africa represent the national union federations in a specific area.

questions.correct: National union federations, such as the MTUC, work to improve conditions for workers in their member nations.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Tepeapulco is a municipality in the state of Hidalgo, Mexico.
  • Municipalities are governmental regions responsible for providing many public services to their residents.
  • One service they provide is water treatment.
  • Tepeapulco covers an area of roughly 243 km².
  • Hidalgo is divided into 84 municipalities.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize the size of Tepeapulco. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Providing water treatment is just one example of the public services that municipalities provide.

options.name: B
options.content: Tepeapulco--a governmental region in the state of Hidalgo, Mexico--provides many public services to its residents.

options.name: C
options.content: Tepeapulco is one of 84 governmental regions, known as municipalities, across Hidalgo.

options.name: D
options.content: The municipality of Tepeapulco in Hidalgo, Mexico, covers an area of roughly 243 km².

questions.correct: The municipality of Tepeapulco in Hidalgo, Mexico, covers an area of roughly 243 km².

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Most of the plant and bird species in Oahu, Hawaii, are non-native.
  • In a 2019 study, researchers wanted to know what role non-native birds play in dispersing plant seeds in Oahu.
  • Researchers catalogued plant seeds found in fecal samples from non-native birds.
  • Pipturus albidus, a flowering shrub, was one of fifteen native species catalogued.
  • Psidium cattleyanum, a fruit tree, was one of twenty-nine non-native species catalogued.
  • Researchers concluded that non-native birds play a vital role in dispersing the seeds of native and non-native plants.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a difference between the two plants. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Most plant species found in Oahu, Hawaii, like Psidium cattleyanum, are non-native.

options.name: B
options.content: Though Pipturus albidus and Psidium cattleyanum can both be found in Oahu, Hawaii, only the former plant is native.

options.name: C
options.content: A 2019 study catalogued plant seeds found in bird fecal samples in Oahu, Hawaii, to determine what role non-native birds play in seed dispersal.

options.name: D
options.content: Seeds from Pipturus albidus and Psidium cattleyanum plants were found in the fecal samples of non-native Hawaiian birds, according to a 2019 study.

questions.correct: Though Pipturus albidus and Psidium cattleyanum can both be found in Oahu, Hawaii, only the former plant is native.
